page.title: 02Origins of the Wolfords
page.content: The origins of the name Wolford are thought to be unique. It first appeared as Ulware or Ulwarde, then as Wolwarde in the Domesday Book. By 1242 in the Book of Fees the two Wolfords were in existance - Wulleward Magna and Wulleward Parva. The two elements of the name seem to be Old English for 'Wolf' and "Weard", meaning guard, so the name could have come into being because this was an area 'enclosed to protect flocks from wolves'. Since there are physical remains of early earthworks on the north side of Great Wolford perhaps one could take this as corroborative evidence that Wolford did mean 'Protected area'. The present spelling of Todenham appeared in 1291 in the Taxatio Eccleseastica. Earlier in the Domesday Book it was Teodeham and was probably originally Teodas Hamm or Ham.
